Authors:
Jordan S Metzgar, Mackenzie Stamey, Stefanie M.
Ickert-Bond
Title:
Genetic partitioning and polyploid formation within the
Cryptogramma crispa (Polypodiales: Pteridaceae) complex
Keywords:
Cryptogramma, ferns, polyploidy, phylogeography, glacial
refugium
Abstract:
The tetraploid fern Cryptogramma crispa (L.) R.Br. ex
Hook. is distributed across alpine and high latitude regions of Europe
and western Asia and is sympatric with the recently described octoploid
C. bithynica S. Jess., L. Lehm. & Bujnoch in northcentral Turkey.
Our analysis of a 6 locus plastid DNA sequence dataset comprised of 39
accessions of Cryptogramma R.Br., including 14 populations of C. crispa
and one population of C. bithynica, revealed a deep genetic division
between samples of C. crispa from western, northern and central Europe
with populations of C. crispa and C. bithynica from Turkey and the
Caucasus Mountains. This legacy likely results from Pleistocene climate
fluctuations and appears to represent incipient speciation between the
eastern and western clades. These plastid DNA sequence data also
demonstrate that C. crispa, specifically the western Asian clade, is the
maternal parent of C. bithynica. Our analysis of DNA sequence data from
the biparentally inherited nuclear locus gapCp support an autopolyploid
origin of C. bithynica, with C. crispa as the sole progenitor.
